description: Big Island VR location database - panoramas, depth maps, audio settings, atmosphere, educational content, and tours

audio_system.description: Web Audio API-based ambient sound system with location-specific mixes

wind.description: Wind from gentle breeze to strong gusts

rain.description: Rain from light drizzle to heavy tropical rain

volcanic.description: Deep volcanic rumble and geothermal sounds

coffee_farm.description: Coffee farm ambience with machinery and nature

mist.description: Fog/mist overlay for humid or volcanic areas

aloha.meaning: Love, affection, peace, compassion, mercy; hello, goodbye
aloha.usage: Universal greeting expressing warmth and spirit

aina.usage: Refers to the sacred relationship between Hawaiians and the land

mauka.usage: Directional term used instead of north/south

makai.usage: Directional term used instead of north/south

pele.meaning: Goddess of volcanoes, fire, lightning, wind
pele.usage: Central deity in Hawaiian mythology, lives in Kƒ´lauea

ohana.usage: Emphasizes the importance of family bonds

kapu.usage: Refers to ancient Hawaiian system of laws and prohibitions

kipuka.meaning: Oasis of older growth surrounded by younger lava
kipuka.usage: Island of vegetation spared by lava flows

puuhonua.usage: Sacred place where lawbreakers could seek forgiveness

waipio.usage: Name of the famous Valley of the Kings

kilauea.usage: Name of the world's most active volcano

mauna.usage: Used in Mauna Kea (White Mountain) and Mauna Loa (Long Mountain)

honu.usage: Sacred animal in Hawaiian culture, symbol of good luck

lau.usage: Used in many plant names like laupahoehoe (smooth lava leaf)

kai.usage: Common element in place names near the ocean

nalu.usage: He ªe nalu means 'wave sliding' or surfing

kona.usage: Refers to the dry, sunny western coast

cultural_tips.title: Remove Shoes Indoors
cultural_tips.description: Always remove your shoes before entering someone's home or certain establishments. This keeps the home clean and is a sign of respect.

cultural_tips.title: Respect Sacred Sites
cultural_tips.description: Many places are considered sacred (kapu). Follow posted signs, stay on marked trails, and never move or take rocks from heiau (temples).

cultural_tips.title: Don't Take Lava Rocks
cultural_tips.description: Legend says taking lava rocks brings bad luck from Pele. The Park Service receives thousands of returned rocks yearly from people who experienced misfortune.

cultural_tips.title: Give the Shaka
cultural_tips.description: The shaka (thumb and pinky extended) is the universal Hawaiian greeting. It means 'hang loose' and spreads aloha spirit.

cultural_tips.title: Drive with Aloha
cultural_tips.description: Let others merge, don't honk unnecessarily, and wave thank you. Island time is real - slow down and enjoy the journey.

cultural_tips.title: Respect Sea Turtles
cultural_tips.description: Honu (sea turtles) are protected. Keep at least 10 feet away, never touch them, and don't disturb them while resting on beaches.

cultural_tips.title: Learn Basic Hawaiian Words
cultural_tips.description: Locals appreciate when visitors try to pronounce place names correctly. Every vowel is pronounced, and the  ªokina ( ª) is a glottal stop.

cultural_tips.title: Support Local
cultural_tips.description: Buy from local farmers markets, eat at local restaurants, and purchase from local artisans. This directly supports the community.

cultural_tips.title: MƒÅlama  ªƒÄina (Care for the Land)
cultural_tips.description: Pack out what you pack in, use reef-safe sunscreen, and don't disturb wildlife or plants. Leave places better than you found them.

cultural_tips.title: Ask Before Taking Photos
cultural_tips.description: It's respectful to ask permission before photographing people, especially at cultural events or ceremonies.

plants.name: ª≈åhi ªa Lehua
plants.description: Endemic tree with beautiful red flowers. First plant to colonize new lava flows. Sacred to Pele - legend says picking the flower brings rain.

plants.name: Koa
plants.description: Hawaii's largest native tree, prized for its beautiful wood used in furniture and canoes. Can grow to 100 feet tall.

plants.name: Hapu'u Fern
plants.description: Giant tree fern that creates the distinctive rainforest canopy. Can grow 20 feet tall. Pulu (soft fiber) was historically used for stuffing.

plants.name: Ti Plant
plants.description: Sacred plant used for spiritual protection, lei making, and wrapping food. Green ti is most traditional; red varieties are also common.

plants.name: Plumeria
plants.description: Fragrant flowers used in lei making. Not native but deeply associated with Hawaii. Blooms year-round.

plants.name: Bird of Paradise
plants.description: Striking orange and blue flowers resembling tropical birds. Popular in landscaping and flower arrangements.

plants.name: Naupaka
plants.description: Half-flower shaped plant found both on beaches and mountains. Legend tells of separated lovers whose flowers are reunited when placed together.

plants.name: Silversword
plants.description: Extremely rare plant found only on Mauna Kea. Silver leaves reflect sunlight. Blooms once after 50 years, then dies.

animals.name: Honu (Green Sea Turtle)
animals.description: Sacred in Hawaiian culture. Protected species. Often seen basking on beaches or feeding on algae near shore.

animals.name: Humpback Whale
animals.description: Migrate from Alaska to Hawaii each winter to breed. Males sing complex songs. Can grow to 60 feet long.
animals.best_time: November to May, peak in February-March

animals.name: Spinner Dolphin
animals.description: Known for acrobatic spinning leaps. Rest in shallow bays during the day. Protected - maintain distance.

animals.name: Manta Ray
animals.description: Graceful filter feeders with wingspans up to 12 feet. Feed on plankton at night near coast.

animals.name: Hawaiian Monk Seal
animals.description: Critically endangered. One of only two remaining monk seal species. Name means 'dog running in rough seas.'

animals.name: Nƒìnƒì (Hawaiian Goose)
animals.description: State bird of Hawaii. Nearly went extinct (down to 30 birds). Now recovering through conservation efforts.

animals.name: ªI ªiwi (Scarlet Honeycreeper)
animals.description: Brilliant red bird with curved bill for extracting nectar from  ª≈çhi ªa flowers. Declining due to avian malaria.

animals.name: Hawaiian Hawk
animals.description: Endemic hawk found only on Big Island. Considered  ªaumakua (family guardian spirit) by some families.

merrie_monarch.name: Merrie Monarch Festival
merrie_monarch.description: The world's premier hula competition and celebration of Hawaiian culture. Held in Hilo for one week.
merrie_monarch.significance: Named after King David KalƒÅkaua who revived Hawaiian culture. Features solo and group hula kahiko (ancient) and hula  ªauana (modern).
tips: Free events include craft fair and parade
Hilo transforms with decorations and festivities

whale_season.name: Whale Watching Season
whale_season.description: Humpback whales migrate from Alaska to Hawaii to breed and give birth in warm waters.
viewing_tips: Best viewing from elevated coastal areas
Whale watching tours available from Kona and Kawaihae
fun_facts: Calves gain 100 pounds per day drinking mother's milk
They don't eat while in Hawaii (fast for months)
Same whales return to Hawaii year after year

volcanic_activity.name: Volcanic Activity Status
volcanic_activity.kƒ´lauea_info: Kƒ´lauea is one of the world's most active volcanoes. Activity level varies from quiet to spectacular eruptions.
safety_notes: Always check current conditions before visiting
Volcanic gases (vog) can affect air quality
viewing_tips: Eruptions visible from Jaggar Museum overlook area
Best glow viewing at night during active periods
Halema ªuma ªu crater is most active area

winter_spring.notes: Jacaranda blooms paint Hilo purple; best along Saddle Road

spring_summer.notes: Peak plumeria season; gardens are most fragrant

fall_winter.notes: Holiday season brings poinsettias; Hilo orchid farms bloom

hilo_bayfront.name: Hilo Bayfront
hilo_bayfront.description: Explore historic Hilo's bayfront from Banyan Drive to downtown

hawaii_volcanoes.name: Hawaii Volcanoes
hawaii_volcanoes.description: Journey through Hawaii Volcanoes National Park from crater rim to coast

saddle_road.name: Saddle Road
saddle_road.description: Cross the island between Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa

mauna_kea.name: Mauna Kea Summit
mauna_kea.description: Ascend to the summit of Hawaii's tallest peak

kona_coast.name: Kona Coast
kona_coast.description: Sunny Kona from historic pier to marine sanctuaries

coffee_country.name: Coffee Country
coffee_country.description: Tour the world-famous Kona Coffee belt

hamakua_coast.name: Hamakua Coast
hamakua_coast.description: Scenic waterfalls and valleys along the northeast coast

waterfalls.name: Waterfalls Tour
waterfalls.description: Chase the most spectacular waterfalls on the Big Island

south_point.name: South Point
south_point.description: Journey to the southernmost point in the United States

kohala_coast.name: Kohala Coast
kohala_coast.description: Resort coast with ancient Hawaiian sites

north_kohala.name: North Kohala
north_kohala.description: Historic towns and dramatic valleys in North Kohala

historical_hawaii.name: Historical Hawaii
historical_hawaii.description: Ancient Hawaiian sites and places of historical significance

beach_hopper.name: Beach Hopper
beach_hopper.description: Hit the best beaches from black sand to white sand

sunrise_sunset.name: Sunrise to Sunset
sunrise_sunset.description: Best spots for watching sunrise and sunset on the Big Island

locations.name: Banyan Drive Start
locations.description: Historic drive lined with banyan trees planted by celebrities including Amelia Earhart, Babe Ruth, and Franklin D. Roosevelt since the 1930s. Each tree has a plaque identifying who planted it.
locations.extended_description: Banyan Drive is a scenic half-mile stretch in Hilo where celebrities and dignitaries have planted banyan trees since 1933. The tradition began when the area was developed as a resort district. The massive banyans create a dramatic canopy over the road, with aerial roots descending from branches. Walking the drive, you can find trees planted by Cecil B. DeMille, Louis Armstrong, King George V, and many more. The drive connects major hotels with Lili ªuokalani Gardens.

hawaiian_word.meaning: Pandanus tree (also found along the drive)

visitor_tips.parking: Free street parking along Banyan Drive

locations.name: Liliuokalani Gardens
locations.description: Largest authentic ornamental Japanese garden outside of Japan, honoring Japanese immigrants to Hawaii. Features pagodas, koi ponds, bridges, and serene pathways.
locations.extended_description: This 24-acre park is named after Hawaii's last reigning monarch, Queen Lili ªuokalani. Created in the early 1900s to honor Japanese immigrants who worked the sugar plantations, it features traditional Japanese landscaping including stone lanterns, arched bridges, a tea house, pagodas, and a ceremonial tea garden. The gardens offer stunning views of Hilo Bay and are especially beautiful during sunrise when mist often rises from the ponds.

hawaiian_word.meaning: Smarting, referring to Queen Lili ªuokalani

visitor_tips.best_time: Early morning for photos and fewer crowds
visitor_tips.accessibility: Mostly paved paths, some uneven stones

locations.name: Coconut Island Viewpoint
locations.description: View of Moku Ola (Coconut Island) from Liliuokalani Gardens bridge. This small island was once a pu ªuhonua (place of refuge) and healing center.
locations.extended_description: Moku Ola means 'Island of Life' in Hawaiian. In ancient times, it served as a pu ªuhonua where kapu breakers could find sanctuary and healers would treat the sick. The island was believed to have special healing powers. Today it's connected to Lili ªuokalani Gardens by a footbridge and features a swimming area, picnic tables, and jumping tower popular with local families.

locations.name: Hilo Bay Pier
locations.description: Historic pier with panoramic views of Hilo Bay, Mauna Kea, and cruise ships when in port. A hub of local fishing activity.
locations.extended_description: This working pier is the heart of Hilo's maritime activity. On clear days, the view extends from Mauna Kea to Mauna Loa. The pier hosts the weekly Wednesday and Saturday Hilo Farmers Market nearby. Fishermen cast lines from the pier while locals stroll the waterfront. During cruise ship season, massive vessels dock here, transforming the quiet town into a bustling port.

locations.name: Downtown Hilo
locations.description: Historic downtown with classic Hawaiian storefronts, art galleries, and the famous Hilo Farmers Market.
locations.extended_description: Downtown Hilo retains its old Hawaii charm with buildings dating to the early 1900s. Many storefronts have been preserved or restored after devastating tsunamis in 1946 and 1960. The area features local boutiques, galleries, cafes, and the incredible Hilo Farmers Market (Wed & Sat). The Pacific Tsunami Museum tells the story of the waves that shaped this resilient community. Walking downtown reveals why Hilo is often called the 'City of Rainbows.'

hawaiian_word.meaning: To twist, braid (also the name for new moon)

visitor_tips.parking: Metered street parking; free lots nearby
visitor_tips.best_time: Wednesday or Saturday morning for Farmers Market

locations.name: Rainbow Falls
locations.description: WaiƒÅnuenue - iconic 80-foot waterfall just outside Hilo. Named for the rainbows that form in its mist on sunny mornings.
locations.extended_description: WaiƒÅnuenue means 'rainbow water' in Hawaiian. This 80-foot waterfall plunges into a large pool surrounded by wild ginger and tropical vegetation. The cave behind the falls is said to be the home of Hina, goddess of the moon and mother of the demigod Maui. For the best chance to see rainbows, visit between 9-11am when the sun angle is right. A short paved path leads to an overlook, and another trail goes above the falls to a massive banyan tree.

locations.name: Park Entrance
locations.description: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park entrance gate - gateway to one of the world's most active volcanic landscapes.
locations.extended_description: This entrance marks the beginning of your journey into Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, home to two of the world's most active volcanoes: Kƒ´lauea and Mauna Loa. The park encompasses 333,308 acres ranging from sea level to 13,681 feet. As you enter, you're crossing into a landscape constantly being created and destroyed by volcanic forces. The park has been designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site and International Biosphere Reserve.

locations.name: Kilauea Visitor Center
locations.description: Main visitor center with exhibits on volcanism, Hawaiian culture, and park orientation. Starting point for many hikes.
locations.extended_description: The Kƒ´lauea Visitor Center is your first stop for understanding the park. Interactive exhibits explain volcanic processes, Hawaiian legends about Pele, and the unique ecosystems that thrive here. Rangers provide current eruption updates, trail conditions, and safety information. The center shows a 20-minute film about the park and sells maps, books, and volcano-themed gifts. Outside, you can begin the Volcano Art Center trail.

locations.name: Steam Vents
locations.description: Geothermal steam rising from volcanic fissures along Crater Rim Drive. Feel the heat of the volcano beneath your feet.
locations.extended_description: At Steam Vents, groundwater seeps down through the earth, is heated by magma, and rises back as steam through cracks in the ground. The steam can reach temperatures of 200¬∞F or higher. On cool, humid mornings, the vents are particularly dramatic. The nearby Steaming Bluff offers views where steam billows from the cliff face. This is a visceral reminder that you're standing on an active volcano.

locations.name: Jaggar Museum Overlook
locations.description: Overlook of Kilauea caldera (museum closed but viewpoint accessible). One of the best vantage points to view Halema ªuma ªu crater.
locations.extended_description: Though the Thomas A. Jaggar Museum was damaged in the 2018 eruption and remains closed, the overlook area provides some of the best views of Kƒ´lauea caldera and Halema ªuma ªu crater. On active days, you might see volcanic glow after dark. The overlook honors Thomas Jaggar, founder of the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory who dedicated his life to volcano monitoring. This spot offers spectacular sunset viewing.

visitor_tips.hours: Check park website - may close due to volcanic activity
visitor_tips.best_time: Sunset or after dark during active eruptions

locations.name: Halema'uma'u Crater
locations.description: Active volcanic crater within Kilauea caldera - legendary home of Pele, goddess of fire and volcanoes.
locations.extended_description: Halema ªuma ªu means 'house of the  ªama ªu fern' and is the mythological home of Pele. This crater within a crater has been the site of dramatic volcanic activity for centuries. The 2018 eruption dramatically changed the landscape, causing the crater floor to collapse 1,600 feet. During active periods, a lava lake may be visible, creating an otherworldly glow. Hawaiians consider this one of the most sacred places in the islands.

hawaiian_word.meaning: House of the  ªama ªu fern

locations.name: Thurston Lava Tube
locations.description: Walk through a 500-year-old lava tube surrounded by lush rainforest. A natural tunnel formed by flowing lava.
locations.extended_description: NƒÅhuku (Thurston Lava Tube) offers a walk through a 500-year-old lava tube formed when the surface of a lava flow cooled while molten lava continued flowing beneath, eventually draining to leave a hollow tube. The tube is approximately 450 feet long and tall enough to walk through upright. The surrounding rainforest is home to native birds and giant tree ferns. Named for Lorrin A. Thurston, a newspaper publisher who helped establish the park.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved with stairs and low clearance in spots

locations.name: Chain of Craters Road
locations.description: Scenic 18-mile road descending through lava fields to the coast. Passes numerous craters and petroglyphs.
locations.extended_description: Chain of Craters Road descends 3,700 feet over 18 miles through some of the most dramatic volcanic landscapes on Earth. The road passes pit craters including Lua Manu, Pu ªu Huluhulu, and Makaopuhi. Along the way, you'll see lava flows from different eruptions, each with distinct textures and colors. The road ends abruptly where 2003 lava flows covered it. Look for petroglyphs at Pu ªu Loa, one of Hawaii's largest collections.

locations.name: Holei Sea Arch
locations.description: Natural lava rock arch at the end of Chain of Craters Road where ancient flows meet the Pacific Ocean.
locations.extended_description: At the end of Chain of Craters Road, violent waves have carved this dramatic 90-foot-high sea arch from volcanic rock. The coastline here shows the ongoing battle between Pele (volcano) and her sister Namakaokahai (sea). The area features a short trail along the cliffs with views of the arch and the dramatic intersection of lava and ocean. Bring water and sun protection - there is no shade.

locations.name: Saddle Road Start (Hilo Side)
locations.description: Beginning of Saddle Road from Hilo side - the scenic route crossing between Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa.
locations.extended_description: Daniel K. Inouye Highway (Saddle Road) offers one of the most dramatic drives in Hawaii. From Hilo, the road climbs through rainforest, transitions to semi-arid shrubland, and opens to vast views of both massive volcanoes. The journey showcases multiple climate zones in just 50 miles. Once notorious for its narrow curves, the road has been modernized while retaining its scenic grandeur.

locations.name: Mauna Kea Access Road
locations.description: Junction of Saddle Road and Mauna Kea summit access. The turnoff to Hawaii's tallest peak.
locations.extended_description: This junction marks the beginning of the climb to Mauna Kea's summit, which rises 13,796 feet above sea level (and over 32,000 feet from the seafloor, making it Earth's tallest mountain base-to-peak). From here, the access road climbs through rare ecosystems including the silversword habitat. The Visitor Information Station at 9,200 feet is the mandatory acclimatization stop before the summit.

locations.name: Mauna Kea Visitor Information Station
locations.description: Visitor center at 9,200 feet - the gateway to Mauna Kea summit. Offers stargazing programs and acclimatization stop.
locations.extended_description: The Visitor Information Station (VIS) sits at 9,200 feet, roughly halfway to the summit. Visitors must stop here to acclimatize before continuing to the summit at 13,796 feet. The VIS offers educational exhibits about Mauna Kea's cultural and scientific significance, restrooms, and warm drinks. Free nightly stargazing programs (weather permitting) use powerful telescopes to view planets, nebulae, and galaxies.

hawaiian_word.meaning: Cloud, light, day (referring to the summit above clouds)

visitor_tips.best_time: Arrive by sunset for stargazing programs

locations.name: Mauna Kea Summit Observatories
locations.description: World's premier astronomical observatory site at 13,796 feet. Home to 13 telescopes operated by eleven countries.
locations.extended_description: The summit of Mauna Kea hosts the world's largest observatory for optical, infrared, and submillimeter astronomy. The site was chosen for its dark skies, dry atmosphere, stable airflow, and position above 40% of Earth's atmosphere. Telescopes include the Keck Observatories (world's largest optical telescopes), Subaru, and Gemini North. While sacred to Hawaiians, the summit represents the cutting edge of human cosmic exploration.

visitor_tips.hours: 30 minutes before sunset to 30 minutes after sunrise
visitor_tips.best_time: Sunset for views, predawn for astronomy
visitor_tips.accessibility: 4WD vehicle required; altitude can cause illness

locations.name: Pu'u Huluhulu
locations.description: Forested cinder cone between Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa offering panoramic views of both volcanoes.
locations.extended_description: This kipuka (vegetated island surrounded by younger lava) rises between Hawaii's two largest volcanoes. A 20-minute hike through native dryland forest leads to the summit with 360-degree views of Mauna Kea, Mauna Loa, and HualƒÅlai. The name means 'very hairy hill' referring to its dense vegetation. The area is home to native birds including the endangered palila.

locations.name: Kipuka Ki
locations.description: Island of old forest surrounded by younger lava flows - a living laboratory of island ecology.
locations.extended_description: Kipuka Ki is a perfect example of how lava flows can isolate pockets of older vegetation. When surrounding areas were covered by lava, this 'island' of native forest was spared, preserving species that died out elsewhere. Today it serves as an important seed source for native plants and habitat for endangered birds. The contrast between the verdant kipuka and surrounding barren lava demonstrates the regenerative power of Hawaii's ecosystems.

hawaiian_word.meaning: Oasis of older vegetation spared by lava

locations.name: Saddle Summit
locations.description: Highest point of Saddle Road at 6,632 feet - the crossing point between east and west Hawaii.
locations.extended_description: At 6,632 feet, this is the highest point on Saddle Road and marks the divide between windward (rainy) and leeward (dry) Hawaii. On clear days, you can see both Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa towering above. The landscape here is stark and beautiful - alpine shrubland transitioning to mƒÅmane-naio forest. Military training areas flank the road, remnants of World War II installations.

locations.name: Kailua-Kona Pier
locations.description: Historic pier in downtown Kona - starting point for fishing charters and the Iron Man triathlon finish line.
locations.extended_description: Kailua Pier is the heart of historic Kona town. Built in the 1900s for inter-island shipping, today it's the departure point for fishing charters, snorkel cruises, and whale watching tours. Each October, triathletes swim past the pier to start the Ironman World Championship. Nearby are Hulihe ªe Palace (former vacation home of Hawaiian royalty) and Mokuaikaua Church (oldest Christian church in Hawaii).

visitor_tips.parking: Paid lots nearby; street parking limited

locations.name: Ali'i Drive
locations.description: Scenic oceanfront drive through Kona lined with shops, restaurants, and historic sites.
locations.extended_description: Ali'i (meaning 'chief' or 'royalty') Drive stretches from Kailua-Kona south to Keauhou. This beautiful waterfront road passes beaches, tide pools, and resort properties. Walking or biking reveals hidden gems: the Hulihe ªe Palace, Mokuaikaua Church, and numerous excellent restaurants. The drive offers consistent ocean views and is particularly beautiful at sunset when the water glows gold.

locations.name: Magic Sands Beach
locations.description: Popular beach known for disappearing sand - waves sometimes remove all sand overnight, revealing lava rocks.
locations.extended_description: Also called LƒÅ ªaloa Beach or White Sands, this beach earned the nickname 'Magic Sands' because powerful winter swells can sweep away the entire sandy beach overnight, leaving only rocks. Days later, the sand magically reappears as currents deposit it back. When sand is present, it's one of Kona's best bodyboarding spots with consistent shore break. Strong currents require caution.

locations.name: Kahalu'u Beach Park
locations.description: Premier snorkeling beach with abundant sea turtles and tropical fish in a protected bay.
locations.extended_description: Kahalu ªu is arguably the best easy-access snorkeling spot on the Big Island. A natural breakwater protects the shallow bay, creating calm conditions perfect for beginners. Sea turtles (honu) graze on algae-covered rocks while colorful reef fish dart through the water. The beach park has facilities, lifeguards, and equipment rentals. Ancient Hawaiians used this area for aquaculture.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved to water's edge; sandy entry

locations.name: Keauhou Bay
locations.description: Historic bay known for manta ray night dives and as the birthplace of King Kamehameha III.
locations.extended_description: Keauhou Bay holds deep historical significance as the birthplace of Kauikeaouli (King Kamehameha III), who was born prematurely and revived by a kahuna at a nearby heiau. Today, the bay is famous for manta ray night dives - boats anchor here as mantas come to feed on plankton attracted by lights. The calm waters also offer excellent kayaking and stand-up paddleboarding.

locations.name: Kealakekua Bay
locations.description: Marine sanctuary and site of Captain Cook's death. Premier snorkeling in crystal-clear waters.
locations.extended_description: Kealakekua means 'pathway of the god' - ancient Hawaiians believed their gods descended to this bay. Captain James Cook was killed here in 1779 after being mistaken for the god Lono, then later worshipped and finally confronted. A white monument across the bay marks the site. Today, the bay is a Marine Life Conservation District with some of Hawaii's best snorkeling. Spinner dolphins often rest here in mornings.

visitor_tips.parking: Limited at NƒÅp≈ç ªopo ªo; kayak tours available
visitor_tips.best_time: Morning for dolphins and calm water
visitor_tips.accessibility: Steep hike to monument; boat/kayak recommended

locations.name: Pu'uhonua o Honaunau
locations.description: Place of Refuge - ancient sanctuary where kapu breakers could be absolved. Sacred ground with temple reconstructions.
locations.extended_description: This National Historical Park preserves one of Hawaii's most sacred sites. In ancient Hawaii, breaking kapu (sacred laws) was punishable by death. The only escape was to reach a pu ªuhonua, where a kahuna would perform ceremonies to absolve the transgressor. The site includes reconstructed tiki, a temple, royal fishponds, and the famous Ki'i (carved wooden images). The waters offshore are excellent for snorkeling among sea turtles.

locations.name: Holualoa Village
locations.description: Charming artist village in the heart of Kona coffee country. Galleries, studios, and coffee farms.
locations.extended_description: Perched on the slopes of HualƒÅlai at 1,400 feet, Holualoa is a peaceful artist community surrounded by coffee farms. The main street features galleries, studios, and the Kona Coffee & Tea Company. The cooler temperatures and afternoon mists create perfect coffee-growing conditions. Walking through town feels like stepping back in time, with plantation-era buildings now housing artists and craftspeople.

locations.name: Mountain Thunder Coffee
locations.description: Working Kona coffee farm offering tours through the entire coffee process from tree to cup.
locations.extended_description: Mountain Thunder is one of Kona's largest organic coffee producers, farming 36 acres of premium coffee. Their comprehensive tours explain every step of coffee production: growing, hand-picking, wet and dry processing, roasting, and cupping. Located at 3,200 feet elevation, the farm enjoys ideal coffee-growing conditions. Visitors can taste different roasts and learn why Kona coffee commands premium prices worldwide.

locations.name: Greenwell Farms
locations.description: Historic 100+ acre Kona coffee farm operating since 1850. Free tours through working coffee plantation.
locations.extended_description: Greenwell Farms represents five generations of Kona coffee farming since 1850. The farm covers over 100 acres and produces some of the most sought-after Kona coffee. Free walking tours explain the heritage of coffee in Kona, from its introduction in the 1800s through today's artisan roasting. The gift shop offers fresh-roasted coffee and local products. The farm also grows macadamia nuts, avocados, and tropical fruits.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved paths on main tour route

locations.name: Kona Coffee Living History Farm
locations.description: Working farm museum recreating a 1920s-era Japanese coffee farm. Experience heritage farming methods.
locations.extended_description: This unique living history farm recreates the life of a Japanese immigrant coffee farming family in the 1920s-30s. Costumed interpreters demonstrate traditional farming techniques, from hand-picking cherry to pulping and drying. The farm includes a restored farmhouse, traditional Japanese bath house (fur≈ç), and processing facilities. Learn how Japanese immigrants shaped Kona's coffee industry and culture.

locations.name: Captain Cook Town
locations.description: Small upcountry town in the heart of coffee country. Named for the famous explorer.
locations.extended_description: Captain Cook is a small community at 1,500 feet elevation on the slopes above Kealakekua Bay where Captain James Cook met his death in 1779. The town serves as the commercial center for the surrounding coffee farms. Along the main road you'll find local restaurants, coffee shops, and the headquarters of several well-known coffee brands. The elevated location offers cooler temperatures and occasional misty afternoons.

locations.name: Akaka Falls
locations.description: Stunning 442-foot waterfall in lush rainforest, accessed via a beautiful loop trail through tropical vegetation.
locations.extended_description: ªAkaka Falls plunges 442 feet into a gorge surrounded by dense tropical vegetation including bamboo, ferns, orchids, and azaleas. The 0.4-mile loop trail passes through this magnificent rainforest garden before reaching the overlook. Along the way, you'll also see Kah≈´nƒÅ Falls (100 feet). The area receives 90 inches of rain annually, creating this incredibly lush environment. Legend says Akaka was a chief who fell to his death while being pursued by jealous wives.

visitor_tips.fees: $5 per person (Hawaii residents free with ID)
visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved trail with some stairs (over 500 steps)

locations.name: Hawaii Tropical Bioreserve & Garden
locations.description: Spectacular 40-acre botanical garden along Onomea Bay featuring over 2,000 species of tropical plants.
locations.extended_description: This world-class botanical garden occupies a valley along the scenic Pepe'ekeo coast. Trails wind through diverse collections including palms, heliconias, bromeliads, orchids, and rare native Hawaiian plants. The garden features stunning ocean views, waterfalls, lily ponds, and a Japanese garden. Founded in 1984 by Dan Lutkenhouse, it's dedicated to preserving tropical ecosystems. The lush setting has been featured in numerous films.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Steep grades on some trails; golf cart tours available

locations.name: Onomea Bay
locations.description: Beautiful bay along the Pepe'ekeo Scenic Drive, part of the Tropical Bioreserve's coastal area.
locations.extended_description: Onomea Bay is a dramatic section of coastline where jungle meets sea. The bay is viewed from the Tropical Bioreserve and from the scenic drive above. Steep cliffs drop to the turquoise water below. The area was once home to a sugar plantation; remnants of the old railway are still visible. The bay's name means 'pleasant sands' though access to the water is limited.

locations.name: Pepeekeo Scenic Drive
locations.description: 4-mile scenic detour through lush rainforest with old bridges, waterfalls, and ocean views.
locations.extended_description: This short but spectacular route was once the main coastal highway. Today it's a scenic detour through some of the Big Island's most beautiful terrain. The narrow road winds past vintage wooden bridges, cascading streams, and thick jungle vegetation. The area receives over 100 inches of rain annually, creating an incredibly lush environment. Pull off at small viewpoints to appreciate waterfalls and coastal vistas.

locations.name: Waipio Valley Lookout
locations.description: Breathtaking overlook of the Valley of the Kings - sacred home to Hawaiian royalty with black sand beach and waterfalls.
locations.extended_description: Waipi ªo means 'curved water' referring to the stream that winds through this mile-wide, six-mile-deep valley. This was the political and spiritual center of ancient Hawaii, home to high chiefs and the site of important temples. The valley floor is accessible via an incredibly steep road (25% grade, 4WD only) or guided tour. From above, you see black sand beach, twin waterfalls (Hi'ilawe at 1,200 feet), and taro fields that once fed thousands.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved lookout area; valley access extremely steep

locations.name: Honoka'a Town
locations.description: Charming historic plantation town featuring antique shops, local restaurants, and the historic People's Theatre.
locations.extended_description: Honoka'a was once a thriving sugar plantation town. When sugar declined, the town reinvented itself as an arts and antiques destination. The historic main street features preserved buildings from the plantation era now housing galleries, vintage shops, and local eateries. The Honoka'a People's Theatre, built in 1930, still shows movies. The town hosts the annual Honoka'a Western Week, a celebration of its paniolo (cowboy) heritage.

locations.name: Laupahoehoe Point
locations.description: Scenic lava peninsula with powerful surf and memorial to those lost in the 1946 tsunami.
locations.extended_description: This flat lava peninsula juts into the Pacific, creating dramatic surf views. The point is most known for the tragic 1946 tsunami that destroyed the school located here, killing 21 students and 4 teachers. A memorial stands in their honor. The area has been converted to a beautiful county park with pavilions, restrooms, and excellent views of the rugged Hamakua coastline. The name means 'leaf of pahoehoe lava.'

locations.name: South Point Road
locations.description: Scenic drive to the southernmost point in the USA, passing wind farms and pastoral ranchland.
locations.extended_description: This 12-mile road leads from Highway 11 to Ka Lae (South Point). The drive passes massive wind turbines, macadamia nut orchards, and open grazing land. The landscape becomes increasingly dramatic as you approach the point. Side roads lead to Green Sand Beach and other coastal sites. The road is paved but narrow with no services - fill up on gas before heading down.

locations.name: Ka Lae (South Point)
locations.description: Southernmost point in the United States - windswept cliffs where Polynesians first landed in Hawaii.
locations.extended_description: Ka Lae ('The Point') is the southernmost point in all 50 United States. Archaeological evidence suggests Polynesian voyagers landed here around 400-800 AD, making it the oldest known Hawaiian settlement. The area features ancient canoe mooring holes carved into the rock, stone fishing temples, and strong winds that power nearby wind farms. Local fishermen still use the cliff to access prime fishing grounds via ropes and ladders.

locations.name: Green Sand Beach Trailhead
locations.description: Starting point for hike to Papak≈çlea Green Sand Beach - one of only four green sand beaches in the world.
locations.extended_description: From this trailhead, a 2.5-mile hike (each way) leads to Papak≈çlea, one of Earth's rarest beaches. The green color comes from olivine, a semi-precious mineral created in volcanic eruptions. The olivine crystals are heavier than other particles and concentrate here in a cinder cone eroded by waves. The hike traverses windswept coastal terrain with no shade. Some visitors arrange rides with local shuttle operators.

hawaiian_word.meaning: Plover flat (bird that frequents the area)

visitor_tips.accessibility: Difficult 5-mile round trip hike on uneven terrain

locations.name: Punalu'u Black Sand Beach
locations.description: Famous black sand beach where Hawaiian green sea turtles frequently rest. One of Hawaii's most photographed beaches.
locations.extended_description: Punalu'u is the Big Island's most accessible black sand beach. The striking black sand was created by basaltic lava fragmenting as it met the ocean. Hawaiian green sea turtles (honu) frequently haul out on this beach to rest, making it a premier wildlife viewing spot. Please maintain a 10-foot distance from turtles and never touch them. The beach park has facilities, freshwater springs bubble up through the sand.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved to beach edge; sand walking required

locations.name: Na'alehu Town
locations.description: Southernmost town in the United States. Small community with local bakeries and authentic Hawaiian atmosphere.
locations.extended_description: NƒÅ'ƒÅlehu is America's southernmost town. This small community on Highway 11 serves the surrounding ranching area. The town's main draw is the Punalu'u Bake Shop, famous for its malasadas and sweetbread, and other local eateries. The area has a laid-back, authentic Hawaiian feel far from the tourist centers. Mark Twain reputedly planted a monkeypod tree here in 1866 (it was sadly vandalized but regrew).

locations.name: Hapuna Beach
locations.description: Consistently rated one of America's best beaches. Half mile of white sand with perfect swimming conditions.
locations.extended_description: Hapuna Beach is widely considered the Big Island's finest white sand beach and regularly appears on 'best beaches' lists. The half-mile crescent of fine white sand slopes gently into crystal-clear water perfect for swimming, bodyboarding, and snorkeling. The beach park has excellent facilities including restrooms, showers, and a food concession. Winter waves can be powerful - check conditions before swimming.

visitor_tips.best_time: Morning for calm water; avoid winter high surf
visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved to sand; lifeguards on duty

locations.name: Spencer Beach Park
locations.description: Family-friendly beach with calm, protected waters perfect for keiki (children) and beginning snorkelers.
locations.extended_description: Spencer Beach is one of the safest swimming beaches on the Big Island. A fringing reef protects the shore, creating calm water perfect for families with young children. The beach has excellent facilities including pavilions, restrooms, showers, and camping sites. Historically, ancient Hawaiian royalty used this area, and the famous Pu ªukoholƒÅ Heiau is just north of the beach. The calm waters offer easy snorkeling.

visitor_tips.best_time: Any time; water is almost always calm

locations.name: Puukohola Heiau
locations.description: Massive temple built by King Kamehameha I to fulfill prophecy and unite the Hawaiian Islands.
locations.extended_description: Pu ªukoholƒÅ Heiau National Historic Site preserves one of Hawaii's most significant cultural places. King Kamehameha I built this massive temple between 1790-1791 after a prophet told him that doing so would ensure his conquest of the islands. The walls are 224 feet long by 100 feet wide, built without mortar using water-worn basalt stones. After sacrificing his rival Ke≈çua here, Kamehameha did unite Hawaii. The site remains sacred.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Paved paths; temple viewing area accessible

locations.name: Kawaihae Harbor
locations.description: Main commercial harbor for West Hawaii and departure point for many ocean adventures.
locations.extended_description: Kawaihae Harbor serves as the primary port for the Kohala Coast and northern Big Island. Container ships, fuel barges, and cruise ship tenders use the commercial port. The small boat harbor is departure point for snorkel cruises, fishing charters, and whale watching tours. The harbor area includes a few restaurants and shops. King Kamehameha landed his invasion fleet here when conquering Maui.

hawaiian_word.meaning: The water of wrath (referring to ancient battle)

locations.name: Mauna Lani Resort
locations.description: Luxury resort area with ancient Hawaiian fishponds, petroglyph fields, and world-class golf.
locations.extended_description: Mauna Lani ('mountain reaching heaven') resort sits on 3,200 acres of the Kohala Coast. The area preserves significant cultural sites including ancient fishponds still in use, extensive petroglyph fields, and historic trails. The resort developers worked with Hawaiian cultural practitioners to ensure respectful stewardship. Walking trails allow visitors to explore the KalƒÅhuipua'a Fishponds and Puak≈ç Petroglyph Archaeological Preserve.

visitor_tips.fees: Free for walking trails; resort amenities for guests
visitor_tips.accessibility: Some paved trails; others on rough lava

locations.name: Puako Petroglyph Fields
locations.description: One of Hawaii's largest collections of ancient petroglyphs - over 3,000 rock carvings on coastal lava.
locations.extended_description: The Puak≈ç Petroglyph Archaeological Preserve contains over 3,000 rock carvings, one of the largest concentrations in Hawaii. The images include human figures, animals, circles, and cryptic symbols whose meanings are debated. Many were carved by travelers along the ancient trail. A 1.4-mile trail from Mauna Lani leads to the viewing area. Stay on the designated path to protect this irreplaceable cultural heritage.

visitor_tips.best_time: Morning or late afternoon for best lighting
visitor_tips.accessibility: Uneven lava rock trail; 1.4 miles round trip

locations.name: Waimea Town
locations.description: Upcountry cowboy town on the green slopes of Mauna Kea. Home to Hawaii's paniolo (cowboy) heritage.
locations.extended_description: Waimea (also called Kamuela) is a unique upcountry town at 2,700 feet elevation with a decidedly Western feel. This is paniolo (Hawaiian cowboy) country - working ranches have operated here since the 1840s when Mexican vaqueros taught Hawaiians to herd cattle. The town features excellent restaurants, locally made chocolates, and the original location of the famous Parker Ranch, one of America's largest cattle ranches.

visitor_tips.best_time: Any time; cooler temperatures than coast

locations.name: Kohala Mountain Road Lookout
locations.description: Scenic viewpoint on Highway 250 with sweeping views of the Kohala Coast and five volcanoes.
locations.extended_description: Highway 250 (Kohala Mountain Road) traverses the western slopes of the Kohala Mountains, providing some of the Big Island's most spectacular vistas. On clear days, you can see five volcanoes: Mauna Kea, Mauna Loa, HualƒÅlai, Kohala, and distant HaleakalƒÅ on Maui. The road passes through pastoral ranch country with rolling green hills that look more like Ireland than tropical Hawaii. Multiple pullouts offer photo opportunities.

locations.name: Hawi Town
locations.description: Artsy former sugar plantation town at the northern tip of the island with galleries, cafes, and aloha spirit.
locations.extended_description: HƒÅwƒ´ was once the commercial center for the Kohala Sugar Company. When the plantation closed in 1975, the town nearly died but was reborn as an artist community. Today, colorful restored buildings house galleries, boutiques, and restaurants. The town has a funky, laid-back vibe far from tourist centers. It serves as the gateway to Pololu Valley and the end of the King Kamehameha statue tour.

locations.name: King Kamehameha Statue (Kapaau)
locations.description: Original King Kamehameha statue - the one that was lost at sea and later recovered. Most photographed in Honolulu is a replica of this.
locations.extended_description: This is the original King Kamehameha statue, commissioned in 1878 and created in Paris by American sculptor Thomas Gould. The statue was lost at sea off the Falkland Islands but was later recovered and brought here to Kapa ªau, Kamehameha's birthplace in North Kohala. Meanwhile, a replica was made and stands in Honolulu - that one is more famous, but this original has deeper significance. Each year on Kamehameha Day (June 11), the statue is draped with flower lei.

hawaiian_word.meaning: The lonely one / the one set apart

locations.name: Pololu Valley Lookout
locations.description: Dramatic viewpoint overlooking remote black sand beach and rugged sea cliffs at the end of Highway 270.
locations.extended_description: Polol≈´ Valley marks the northern end of the highway and the beginning of a series of remote, inaccessible valleys extending to Waipi ªo. From the lookout, see the black sand beach, valley floor, and dramatic sea cliffs stretching into the distance. A steep 20-minute trail descends to the beach, but swimming is dangerous due to strong currents. The valley was once populated and cultivated with taro, now it's wild and windswept.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Lookout accessible; trail to beach is very steep

locations.name: Lapakahi State Historical Park
locations.description: Preserved 600-year-old Hawaiian fishing village with restored structures and interpretive trails.
locations.extended_description: Lapakahi preserves the remains of a 600-year-old Hawaiian fishing village. The self-guided trail (about 1 mile) passes through restored house sites, fishing shrines, canoe sheds, and salt-making pans. Interpretive signs explain traditional Hawaiian coastal life. The park sits on an arid, windswept coast that looks much as it did centuries ago. The site is sacred - stay on marked trails and don't disturb any rocks.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Unpaved trail with some uneven terrain

locations.name: Mookini Heiau
locations.description: One of Hawaii's oldest and most sacred temples, built around 480 AD. Accessible only by dirt road.
locations.extended_description: Mo ªokini Heiau is among Hawaii's most sacred and ancient sites, built around 480 AD according to legend. The heiau (temple) was used for human sacrifices and restricted to high chiefs and priests. It's near Kamehameha's birthplace. The current kahuna nui (high priestess), a descendant of the Mo ªokini family, lifted the kapu (restriction) in 1978, allowing public visits. Approach with utmost respect.

visitor_tips.best_time: Any time; come with respectful intention

locations.name: Mauna Kea Beach
locations.description: Pristine crescent beach at the historic Mauna Kea Beach Hotel, open to the public with limited parking.
locations.extended_description: Kauna'oa Beach at the Mauna Kea Beach Hotel is one of the Big Island's most beautiful white sand beaches. The crescent bay offers excellent swimming and snorkeling. While the hotel is private, Hawaiian law requires public beach access. Public parking is limited to 30 spaces, available first-come-first-served. Arrive early, especially on weekends, as parking fills by 9am. The beach has restrooms and the hotel allows beach goers to purchase food.

locations.name: Umauma Falls
locations.description: Three-tiered 100-foot waterfall viewable from a private garden, with zipline and swimming options.
locations.extended_description: Umauma Falls is a spectacular three-tiered waterfall plunging 100 feet through lush tropical vegetation. Located on private land, the falls are accessible through the World Botanical Gardens or Umauma Experience tour operators. Options include simple garden tours, swimming at the base of the falls, and ziplines over the cascades. The area receives abundant rainfall, keeping the falls flowing year-round.

visitor_tips.accessibility: Varies by tour; some accessible options
